Review Text: No parents were consulted during the making or design of this device.Been playing with the glow today with my kids.  I feel like it is deceptive as it is just a light, I feel like when I preordered I was led to believe that it was an upgrade to the echo dot.  I was wrong.  It does not add anything in the way of a microphone or speaker.  You just paid $30 for a very simple light that supposedly interacts with your existing echo devices if you say enough words.  Eg you cannot just say “alexa, set rainbow timer for 30 minutes”. You have to address the light specifically “Alexa, set rainbow timer for 30 minutes on <insert device name here>“. Then you get a pretty light and a lot of wires because you have 2 devices plugged in rather than 1.I would rather pay $50 for a device that had a speaker and microphone with a smaller footprint.  I have plenty of smart bulbs and more than enough usb cables running around the house.It gets 2 stars for the rainbow timer feature which allows for my kids to have a visual of how much time is left.Sorry much like the echo auto this is a dud for me.Edit:  2 hours into having it around and a couple more notes:1. Amazon called me for further feedback which was nice. Kudos to support.2. This sucker does not want to be wet (has a warning) so my use case of putting it in the bathroom for a shower or toothbrush timer is a poor idea.  This also means it is a poor choice for a bedside lamp since kids tend to want a glass of water on their bedside.3. Having it in your kid’s bedroom means they need an echo in there.  Parents everywhere, evidently we were not consulted, evidently the developers are unaware of the major distraction an echo after hours can be.  That is mitigated by freetime but guess what is not usable except by touch now?  Echo glow.  And since I cant put it next to the bed...4. Current Use cases:Visual color clock:  there are better cheaper items out there. Onaroo for one.Remote light: Better cheaper solutions for smart homes.  Lifex, hue, etc.Finally I would like to point out that EVERY echo named device to date that I am aware of has a microphone at least.I cannot think of what to do with it so I will be putting it in the kids bathroom with the echo dot that is already there and see how long it lasts.  Maybe I will save some hot water with the rainbow timer.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2019

Review Text: UPDATE: I've had this for another 24 hours and I'm getting the feeling that this was barely tested before releasing it. As mentioned below, you can't turn the Glow off in tap mode unless you use voice commands or open the app. But you also can't use voice commands to set a timer for it. Last night I asked Alexa to turn off the Glow in one hour and it responded that it set a sleep timer. Four hours later, it's still on. I quietly had to tell the Alexa to turn it off now and it woke up the whole GD House with "I DETECT YOU ARE WHISPERING DO YOU WANT TO..."How does Amazon release a devise without testing if you can turn it off?!But the cat still gives it 2 stars.ORIGINAL POST:  I know this is advertised for kids, but I bought it to replace a sun simulation alarm clock and to set up a bedtime routine.  My review is a little mixed because I was able to accomplish these goals (kind of), but the actual "tap" functionality is a bit annoying.  Overall I'm okay with the purchase.  There are some clunky aspects that I'm betting Amazon will iron out soon.The Good:1. I wanted a light that would gradually turn on in the morning, didn't have to be accompanied by an alarm sound, and could be scheduled for weekdays only.  I already returned 2 mid-priced sun simulation lights because they couldn't do this.  (Why is it so hard to find a sun simulator to do those three things?)  I received the Glow and after a few minutes of set-up, I set my first routine using my Alexa app.  It only took a few minutes to program it to do exactly what I wanted.  I could have used a default option to gradually turn the light up, but I went the more complex route of  adding multiple tasks so I could change colors at timed intervals.  I added tasks of light and tasks of "wait" to the routine and it all worked perfectly this morning.2. I was able to set a routine for the Glow to glow blue at night, but I wasn't able to attach it to my current routine of night-time music.  The Glow task does not have a timer feature, so you need to add a "wait" task, then add a task to turn off the Glow.  Unfortunately, there is a requirement that music is the last task in a routine...so unless I want music to turn on after the light turns off, it isn't helpful.  I just made a separate task for the night time light.  So I ask Alexa to "Turn on night time light" and "Turn on night time music."3. The cat discovered the tap feature and is really into it.4. The campfire mode is really cool.  I hope the nifty developers add a cool-tone option so the same effect can be in blues and purple.The Bad:1. It is very sensitive. I had it sitting on the table as I set up my routines and it was constantly changing colors just from the vibrations of the house.  (You can disable the tab feature.)2. You can't turn it off if you use the tap feature.  If you are playing with the color changing taps, it stays on until you go into your app to turn it off, or you give Alexa a voice command to turn it off.  There is a manual button to turn it completely off, but this disables any Alexa connection so routines do not run.You may think that you can hit the button, and then click the button back on, but then the light turns on and you are back to where you started...just wanting to turn the light off without waking people up with a voice command or digging out your phone.  You'd think that a double tap or a long tap would turn the light off...nope..just perpetual light.3. You have to give parental consent to use the light.  I get that Amazon is covering itself by making you virtually sign a consent, but do they have to send a weird email to everyone in the household so that I get a phone calls from my husband asking what I did.  What else is in that light that I need to sign away my rights and inform everyone else in my house that I signed them away?Overall Impressions:This was the same price as the sun simulators I replaced and it brilliantly accomplished that goal. There are some aspects that are still glitchy, but I'm sure Amazon will send out an update to respond to customer feedback.  Amazon is cool like that, and I'll update my review if any of these issues are updated.  If you are buying it for a kid, they will probably like the tap feature and talking to Alexa to get it to respond.  Go for it!
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2019

Review Text: First off, limiting this product marketing to kids is a bad call. I think you'll find there is a much broader audience for this product.Received mine and love the form factor, the light is very nice and bright. The features however cost this review two stars. I am always an early adopter of Alexa technology and I hope, like other products, this too will evolve. Current light settings don't really do much that a typical color smart bulb can't do already. I would very much like to see direct linking to Echo devices so that for alarms you can have a slow sunrise effect to ease your waking transition with an alarm set on your Echo Dot Clock. It would be great to interact more precisely with music playing through a linked device. Additionally I also hope you can also synchronize multiple Glows in future for great effects.So in summary, it's a nice product, I hope it gets better!
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2019

Review Text: I bought this specifically as a wake up (rather - “you can come downstairs“) light for my kids. Meaning at 630 every day, I want the light to turn on to a specific color. A “Green means go” kinda thing.  I have a “dumb” device that does this but it’s a crappy cheap device and needs to be reset too often (power outages, day light savings, etc).To achieve this, I tried to set this up in the device on the echo app, with no luck....I figured it out later that had to set a time based routine.... per the attached picture which took me longer to figure out than it should have.Overall meets my needs and will play with it further.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2019

Review Text: My review this is a solid 5 out of 5 for what it is. I'm 29. I guess I'm not the target demo. This is a cute little light, I like the colors and I like the design. I did not expect anything outside of that. I like the modes, and the brightness setting. I didn't think that it came with the microphone and speakers. I didn't think that it had any other connectivity besides connecting to the app and letting me set different colors and such.1. Setup was easy for me. Connect to wifi, open the app follow instructions, boom it works. If setup was difficult for you then you maybe don't have your WiFi on or your maybe on the wrong network.2. I like that it has several different colors and modes. The campfire mode is cute but could use a little more work (as far as vividness) but for an unexpected mode, I really shouldn't complain.3. I haven't used the tap feature. It has a button on the back that can be used to turn the light on and off....I've just used that whenever I've wanted to physically turn it off. I mostly turn it on and off in the Alexa app as well as set brightness and other modes. I have turned the light on and off via voice command. "Alexa, turn Veronica's light off/on." Easy peasy lemon squeezy turns it on and off.4. I haven't used the timer feature. I didn't buy it for that. I bought it as a cute lamp that interacts with my Alexa app in an easy way. I don't really get the whole productivity light anyway. Is a rainbow timer really going to get anyone to do anything? I'd probably forget I even set it for that.I think if you were disappointed with this product, then you maybe had some incorrect expectations or weird setup issues.So far so good. I like it and plan on getting another one or two for my office. I reaaaalllly want a wall mount with cord wrap for this so I can stick it directly on some sockets.Edit: I have a two socket outlet where I have this plugged up. In one I have my Echo Show the other was free. Didn't want both taken up so I just plugged the cable into a double USB power socket. My cam, show and glow all work just fine with this setup. Not sure why people are saying this will take up extra outlet space. I'm starting to think people want to complain for the sake of complaining.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2019

Review Text: I was one of the early purchasers of this light and had problems from the get go with it. First off, the Wifi was very touchy but I finally got past that by moving the light closer to the router and finally got it to connect. Secondly, Amazon's process for "adult verification" was not working correctly and caused me problems that ended up with me talking to my bank due to the problems Amazon had with the light. I wrote a pretty rough review and was going to return the light, but got a call back from Amazon and we managed to work out an agreement to have them look at what happened to me. I waited for some time for them to get back to me, but evidently we kept missing each other. I resolved to return the light in January, but tried again to get the light registered with Alexa and this time, everything worked. I use mine in my kitchen to save on power for the overhead lights and it is a great little bit of kit. I change the lighting now and again and think it is a pretty awesome little light for what it is.I want to thank Amazon's staff and want to make some suggestions with this light.First off: Adults will be buying this light. Not children. We don't need a nanny-state permission slip to use a light we as adults bought. So my advice to Amazon is to lose the "kids light" feature and make it for everyone.Secondly, I love the "Mode" feature to let you do different presets, but I'd like to see Halloween, Easter, Fall, Spring, Summer and Winter lighting modes along with some kind of color wheel so we can mix and match colors to create lighting similar to the animations like you get with the "Campfire" effect. It would be a nice little add to the Alexa app to control these features and steer more people to this great little light.Third: I'd love to see a family of these evolve from here. I like fiber optic lights and think adding something like this to Alexa control would be really cool to see offered.The Wifi issues seem to be resolved now and I've had a new router installed and it wasn't too tough to reprogram the light to use the new router.In conclusion, it has been a learning experience. I initially was not impressed, but have grown to like this little light. I hope that others don't have to content with the issues I ran into and that Amazon's product development folks listen to the feedback on this. All in all, a great little light and I'm happy with how Amazon actually CALLED ME and listened when I had troubles and then fixed the issues.So would I get it again? I just ordered my second one of these lights to use in another room and hope Amazon realizes more adults will be using these than kids. Yes... even we adults like cool gadgets like this!
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2019

Review Text: So many issues. First, the QR code scan for setup failed with error message and manual setup didn't work. I noticed my phone wifi was off so started all over. QR setup failed and manual setup never found the device. I unplugged and plugged back in and manual setup worked.Next, the primer screen goes on to tell me that I must give parental consent even if there are no children in my household. (I have no children) Then a browser view pops up to show a webpage that asks me to agree to sharing all my personal profiles' info with Amazon and the page is pinch to zoom which caused an issue in that I accidentally caused it to zoom in a lot.During the end of setup I got an app notification saying "Echo Glow isn't quite ready yet" and to go to the Alexa app to complete setup... while I'm in the Alexa app setting it up... and the notification is FROM the app!! Even after completing setup the notification is there.The size of the device was smaller than I expected but that's not a huge deal. The brightness leaves a lot to be desired. The setup showed no details on how to turn it on and off but I found out it's the button on the back. It's extremely awkward to press the button without activating the touch sensitive function that changes the color. Turning it on and off by the physical button leads to inconsistency on the color and brightness you get when it comes back on. Not sure why I can't use touch to turn the device on and off
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2019

Review Text: This is a great little nightlight. Expensive for a nightlight, but lots of nice little features. Works great with an Alexa smart home.Setting up was no more difficult  than other smart products. Which is to say it was a pain in the butt. It never works first time. Ever. After several attempts I was able to get the light to communicate. After setup, it worked better. But then stopped communicating several hours later. Unplugging and plugging back in the light fixed it.Using the light is a breeze. Very responsive and intuitive to basic commands. Alexa makes this super easy.One complaint is the colors seem off. White, purple, red, and green all look okay.  But yellow, gold, pink, and orange look sickly. Orange especially. Doesn't even look close to orange. Honestly, the best color is plain white. I can't fault Amazon to much on the colors. I have a similar night light and have the exact same complaint. I really wish there was a nice Amber color. If a color wheel option was available, one could compensate for the lack of course matching, but sadly the Amazon light doesn't have this. Very disappointing in those regards.One thing I loved about this light are the mood settings. That feature alone is worth the extra $10 (compared to similar products). The campfire and mood modes look great. I wish there were more settings to choose from. Hopefully Amazon can release an update that gives more options.The Amazon quality is evident in this product and I loved that. It doesn't have a battery backup, which is unfortunate. However it has a nice weight and won't roll around. It's smaller than expected, but I liked that. It's about the same size as the Echo Spot.Overall it's a great light. It's a little expensive for the minimal color settings available, but the quality is nice.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2019

Review Text: UPDATE: I have had these in my house for a while now and I'm up to three of them. I love them but to use them as a natural sunrise, you have a lot of work ahead of you. I did a lot of annoying investigation and if you increase the brightness 100% over 20 minutes what happens is from 0 minute to 5 minute it stays at 0 brightness, then at 5 minute it jumps to 25 brightness. Then for minute 5 to minute 10 it stays at 25 the jumps to 50 brightness. Then from minute 10 to minute 15 stays at 50 brightness then jumps 75 brightness. Then at minute 20 it goes to 100% brightness. So it's super annoying but to create the natural sunrise. How I achieve this was by, I put in a 2% brightness then a wait for 2 minutes then a 4% brightness and then I'll wait for 2 minutes, and then I continue on. For me 30% brightness is a good wake up light, so I have it pause there for about 20 minutes before I have it finish out to 100% and then reset to 1% and turn off. I included screen shots so you can see. But once you get it set up correctly it is awesome!!So I bought this for my daughter as a gradual light wake up clock. This takes, in my opinion, some finesse to get it set up right. I included a screenshot of everything I figured out. We also use the light as a "green means go", when she is allowed out of bed if she wakes up but before the light. So it is set at a daily time of 6:45 it turns on green at 50% brightness for half hour and then turns off. So in your routines, you choose your light to turn on whatever color and brightness then you add a wait function for 30 minutes and then you add an off function.So if anyone wants to use it as a natural sunrise there are a couple steps I would recommend. The first step is to turn the light on at a 1% brightness, I would love to use a color but they nearly don't get bright enough at a full 100% to make it actually wake you up, so I used white. Then I put in a wait for 1 minute. Then you do the brightness with the increase, you want to set it to 100% so that it goes from 1% to 100%, I did the duration for half hour, that's your decision. Then I had a wait for 1 minute for when the gradual increase with over. since I wanted it to stay on at 100% for 30 minutes, so it was an on, with brightness at 100%, then another wait for 30 minutes. Then I had it turn off.I love the ability that this is voice activated. Since my daughter's schedule is different every day, once I'm up and I know she needs to be up within a half hour I can turn this on from any of the echoes in my home.Long-term, no idea how this will be. For now and the price it's a pretty good deal
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2019

Review Text: I am very loyal to Amazon.  At last count we have 10-15 Amazon devices in our house.  My wife pre-ordered one of the very first Echos years ago.  We have dots, shows, firesticks, kindles, etc.  So needless to say my kids were very excited when I ordered this.  We received it on November 20, 2019 which I believe was the first day they were available.  My first impression was . . .Meh.  But, I figured it was brand new and they would send out firmware upgrades to give it more usability.  NOPE. . .  Whatever. . .my kids still enjoyed making it change colors.Fast Forward to April 2020.  I upgraded my wifi router which meant that I had to reconnect all my devices.  All my echo devices handled the router change like champs. . . That is except this one.  I may not be an expert, but I am no technical slouch.  So, I contact Amazon technical support and spent two hours on a chat with them going through all the steps to reconnect it.  First they said there was an issue with my Alexa app.  So, uninstalled and reinstalled it. No dice.  They had me do, I don't know how many resets of the glow which did nothing.  We removed it from my devices. . . At one point, it was constantly blinking green and blue, but the tech had no idea what that meant.After about two hours of going through all this, it was finally determined that there is a problem with the device.  Fine. . . send me a replacement.  NO CAN DO.  The warranty already expired. SERIOUSLY?  Yep. . .While all other Echo devices have a one year warranty, for some reason this only has a 90 day warranty.  It's almost as if  they knew that it was a piece of junk.  I even pulled the, "I've been loyal to Amazon since 1998 and have been loyal to Amazon devices" card.  Yeah, I know, not the classiest move.  But, apparently there is nothing that they can do.  Honestly, it is truly disappointing.  Not so much because I'm out the money, but because Amazon won't stand behind their product. . . Oh well.  Live and learn.  But I would definitely not recommend this product.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2020

Review Text: I have a feeling this is a problem with Echo integration and/or Amazon's web service but we have many things that work great with Alexa and this is by far the worst which I find really surprising. Most importantly, when we ask an Echo device to turn this light on or off, we have to do it 3, 4, and sometimes 5 times. What's strange is that "her" response to "turn off 'Blah'" is usually "There is no device named 'Blah'" over and over until it works. It always works eventually. I keep checking to make sure the name is what we think it is in the Alexa app.We can turn on and off every other light, fan, lock any lock, etc. using Alexa and it's great. This device seems to be the only hang up.All that said, the function of the device, when it works, is perfect for our daughter. The "routine" to start ramping up the light level in the morning when we want to wake her up is great but it doesn't start at the assigned time everyday and, with the voice integration being so shaky, I have to use the app to get it going some mornings.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2020

Review Text: We have owned our Glow for about 6mo now. It lived on my 9yo bedside table next to his dot.Pro: Gradual wakeup and rainbow timer (+2 stars), super easy Alexa integration without needing to install another app (+2 stars).Con: Finicky voice commands (-1 star), overpriced for essentially a smart bulb (-1 star), and poor power supply cord execution (-1 star, see picture).As the photo shows, the power cord is connected directly to the Glow rather than have a separate pull out cord. This device has lived on my 9yo's nightstand with very little movement this entire time, and we have cord breakage. I can't imagine this will hold up to the preschool and toddler crowd. I'll have to use my engineering skills to fix the wiring when it finally gives out.tl;dr I wouldn't purchase again and wouldn't recommend for any household with kids younger than 8. Amazon fail.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2020

Review Text: I had been following the Echo devices over the holidays, bought a few more.  I never even noticed this product.  A friend ended up giving it to me for a gift.  I think this would be a pretty cool notification device, changing colors based on events.  I think the Alexa app has enough features, and is extendable through IFTTT and other tools.I tried to do something simple through the Alexa controls--turn on at Sunset, turn off at 11PM.  I don't think it is actually working--the light is on the next morning.  So, not sure about it being reliable for notifications.Otherwise, it works great as a light, is voice controllable, touch works great.  It's reasonably bright for a night-light sort of effect.  So, great for kids, fun for a bit for adults.  We'll see if I can get it to do something actually useful.Oh, and it is super easy to set up, and just as easy if you move from one wifi network to another (tested at friend, then moved to my network).
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2020

Review Text: I have one sitting on my nightstand to give the room a soft light for the dogs. I just ordered two more to use as accent lights throughout the house. I like the different colors you can set it to and the programmed sequences like Campfire are very cool.My only negative is the Alexa app. It's clunky, not simple enough to use and needs a re-engineering effort.In my opinion, Amazon should split device control from the Alexa app and make it a separate app.  And add Apple Shortcut functions so I can control "scenes" and devices from a single button on my iPhone.The only reason I keep buying Echo/Alexa devices instead of switching to Apple Home gear is the price for Alexa/Echo devices is more affordable and the number of different devices available. I love my Echo Input, which kept a small Bluetooth speaker from being moved into the "junk drawer" and I'm holding off in buying the Echo/Alexa Clock until it has a backlight or at least it can be read in a dark room. I like that I can buy "starter items" like the Input and the Dot and eventually move up to a more feature-rich device if I want to.So, a big thumps up for the Echo Glow and Dot and a "Wait-and-see" grade of C+ for the Alexa app.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2020

Review Text: our 10yr old loves this and enjoys changing up all the colors and pattterns it offers and it does make for a great nightlight if needed though you will need to adjust the brightness if you ever wish for them to sleep. We did have several weeks with an issue of it not responding in the app or to the echo dot and it took about 45 minutes of googling to figure out how to resolve the issue, a pain, but it is functioning properly once again.Overall, it's a fun device for the younger kiddos and we look forward to learning more of its functions

Review Text: So for all intents and purposes, this could be a great product. I really liked the features for my daughter's room. She loved it too. It worked fine during setup. Then it eventually became unresponsive. The chat support suggested I move it closer to the router. That was 10 feet away in the next room and when I removed the light and re-added it to my network, of course it worked, just like when I originally set it up. Worked great, again, during setup. However, when I walked away and tried to either turn off the light or turn it back on later, or create a routine for it to go off after my daughter was asleep, it was unresponsive. Sent it back, got a new one. Same thing. So it doesn't like my network, I guess, even though it will work, but not for a long duration. Because I can't call Amazon support due to them not receiving calls (which is kind of ridiculous for a company so large to not have IT work from home), this item is going back. Hopefully it works for others.

Review Text: I preordered 2 of these but then gave as Christmas gifts so I feel lucky I missed the hard set up days because this was a BREEZE to set up.  Why? Because we have amazon products all over and our WiFi password is saved.So I plugged it in scanned the code and boom it was ready! Review Text: So I was mostly planning to use this for the kiddos. They are young enough to need a bunch of help in the morning and it helps if they are at least getting up by the time I get to their rooms. You can set a wake up alarm light timer thru the echo that will give the audio portion of the alarm. You can not set one thru the app, which is inconvenient as you have to remember to mention that it is a wake up alarm, with light x, for what days, and at what time. I wanted to do green for the weekend so they don't get out of bed too early but that doesn't work (I actually wanted a gradually brightening red light that then turns green, no such luck).So basically it has a warm white light you can use for a wake up alarm, it can do a rainbow countdown alarm and otherwise it is a mood light.

Review Text: Originally purchased this to use in a nursery for middle of the night diaper changes. This isn't anything more than a smart colored lamp. It does have some cool functions (camp fire mode is very pretty). I think the value is okay, considering it is comparable to a Hue Color bulb.I'd prefer if it had a dot or full Echo built in to save space on the night stand. I think some of the advertising is/was misleading and some people are expecting that this has an Echo Dot built into the light, which is leading to some disappointment. To be clear, the device is simply a smart lamp, you'll need a smart speaker in addition to this lamp to actually use it. You can tap it to change between the various functions, and a button on the back turns it on and off. You can also speak to any of the smart speakers in your home to change functions, color, or turn it on and off. It's exactly like having a Hue Color Bulb in a normal lamp with some extra specialty lighting modes, and the inclusion of a hardware button to turn on/off.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 24, 2019

Review Text: Do you have a kid who is getting out of bed and coming into your room before they are supposed to and already have an echo dot in their room? This thing actually does work pretty well for my purposes. I needed some kind of light that turned from red to green at a certain time, and then back to red when it was time for bedtime. This makes sense to my son who is 3. He will stay in bed until the light turns green and the second it does, he comes to get us. You can set up different routines for it to change colors and signal your child to keep on a schedule. I love having it but it was very difficult to figure out how to set it up. I ended up calling and the amazon rep helped me set up my schedules and get it working within minutes. If you’re just looking for a light this seems pretty expensive but it is great for a night light and schedule teacher for kids. It is just what the doctor ordered for sleep deprivation.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2019

Review Text: This light is marketed more for children, but it is also great for adults as well.I was looking for one of those lights that are designed to wake you up naturally, but many of them are actually more expensive than this option and this one can do more that just be programed for that function.I like to set it to the campfire mode and use the campfire sounds played via my Amazon Echo Dot, which I find relaxing.If you have children, I think that this is a great light for its intended purpose, but consider it for use in an older child's room or an adult's. Don't let Amazon's marketing turn you off from this product as an option for an adult, they are missing out on a segment of buyers.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2020

Review Text: So I bought this light knowing exactly what I was getting. Some people are extremely confused and think this is a standalone ALEXA item that has ALEXA built in... It is not. It is legit only a light... With me knowing that I still wanted it. I bought it for my daughters room as a night light. They constantly leave the main light on all night and never go to bed. I plugged it in my room first to set up since it was late and they were already in bed... Well. I haven't moved it out of my room yet. I love the thing. Its a nice little light that isnt too bright and I can get ready for work in the mornings without disturbing the wife sleeping. Also a nice mood light. Built in there is about 10 different themes as well accessible through the ALEXA app. Please buy this if your looking for a nice night light or any kind of colorful lighting for your home. It is a companion to your ALEXA devices only.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2019

Review Text: Update: Amazon called and got it working for me. There was an update to the device that I never saw. I had to erase the device again and redo all over again. I have tried restarting the syncing feature with the app several times when I received it but not recently. Review Text: Seriously? There's no way to turn it off without using your voice?! How about enabling a double tap/ tap combo.  Such a simple basic light shouldn't even be branded an "echo" device. Review Text: I bought this nightlight because my child is terrified of being alone in the dark. I expected nothing more than a nightlight and I have been super happy with it. Review Text: We got these as Okay to Wake lights. Needed something that kids couldn’t change the settings on and didn’t want the opportunity to have a sound component. It was great to be able to adjust the brightness as one of children wants it at 3% while sleeping and the other wants it at 25%. I don’t think they even know they can control them through the Echo and that is perfect. My younger child sometimes turns it on or off manually but the routines still take over at the scheduled times. Exactly what we were looking for and cheaper than the alarm clocks with too many features. We started with one and got the second one soon after with how well the first one worked.

Review Text: I'm really glad I got this! We are having a baby soon and I originally wanted to get like a lava lamp or something for his room but saw this shortly after we got our first Alexa device for our house and thought this was a neat idea! Doesn't have a speaker so you need an echo or the Alexa app to use it but that's fine. Has lots of colors and different settings for colors and you can I guess set it on a timer (I tried it once but after the timer was over the light turned off and she played the timer sound... Which was annoying but I probably just said it wrong)? It gets pretty bright which is nice for the morning time so it's not killing your eyes but it's a soft brightness. And it gets dim enough for a nice colorful night light. Super glad I decided on this!

Review Text: Yeah, I know, if you've read my reviews before (especially the ice scraper) you're looking for me to be entertaining... but honestly, I don't fully get this thing. Review Text: Playing with it for 20 min, so far so good. My kid thinks it’s fun. We like the campfire or rainbow light effects and the way you can adjust the brightness and set a color. Review Text: The light is beautiful and fun. Controlling it through Alexa is a hassle. It’s just bright enough to tell it’s on but not bright enough to wake you up if you are still asleep. This is perfect for my kids who share a room and need to be mindful of not waking each other (bedtime or morning). The 1% brightness on other colors is a little more light than I prefer for myself sleeping but it’s perfect for bedtime- gradually dimming the light from 20% to 1%.Only complaint is frustrations with setting it up through Alexa. Review Text: We have 3 of these, one for each kid. My kids love the color changing and adjustable brightness, and especially the ability to control each with Alexa. Review Text: Bought this as a nightlight for my toddlers. Review Text: I've been looking for months for a very small lamp for on top of a hallway corner cabinet. Review Text: I originally bought this for the timer function for my daughter who is easily distracted at night getting ready. Review Text: First off I just want to say that I love this light the reason for the 4 star is this light constantly become unresponsive with my echo as well an in the app. So that is a little frustrating. I just could not find a light that was not too bright and I love that this 100% adjustable. The brightest setting is bright enough to softly illuminate her room so when it comes to bedtime it's perfect for story time and transition into bed time without having to put the main light on. I'm sure as she gets older she will love the colors and other features. So if you want a little light that not that bright and fully adjustable this is great. Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2020

Review Text: Abstract: The device itself works very well. Extremely quick and easy to set up, connect with an Echo device, and the light functions very well and can get surprisingly bright. However, the integration with the Alexa app and its functions still seem limited.First, I will start by saying that I did not purchase this for a child. Rather, I purchased this light with the intention of using it as a wake-up light in conjunction with my Echo alarms. This was not as smooth as I had thought it would be. I also intended to use it as an ambient light in my small room that I could control with my voice from my bed through Echo, which it does very well.After setup, I immediately tried to set up my existing alarms in the Alexa app on my Echo to turn the light on when the alarm begins. That way, there would be both the audible alarm with the light turned on at the same time. I soon learned that this is not possible through the Alexa app. After speaking with customer service for a while, they informed me that this function is not yet accessible. Rather the closest that I can get to this function is to set up a routine in the Alexa app which turns on the light upon dismissal of my alarm. In this way, the alarm sounds without the light on, and when I acknowledge and dismiss the audible alarm, then the light will turn on after. Still a useful function, but not what I wanted.I am mostly frustrated that this option wasn't thought of and there is no current way to enable this in conjunction with an Echo. The customer service representative was polite and kind and said that Amazon is constantly taking feedback for more features, but this one seemed like a no-brainer to me. Oh well, I can only hope that sometime in the near future this will be an option in the alarms on Alexa app.The light itself is great and works very well. Surprisingly bright in my smaller bedroom, and at full power on white color (the brightest color) it illuminates the room enough for me to get clothes from my closet and get ready without turning on my ceiling lights.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2019

Review Text: I received the Echo Glow today. I am really enjoying it. Yes, it is essentially a small globe lamp. You can choose one color, or it can go through a spectrum of colors or themes (or "modes" - rainbow, disco, holidays, siren, campfire, deep ocean, mood light, etc). I as a 34 year old woman love it, my 9 year daughter old loves it. You can tap through the colors, use your Alexa device, or the Alexa app on your phone. (I prefer the phone app because I find it quicker to turn off, dim, or change modes.) Is it worth the retail price of $30? That's iffy, but $5 was a great deal for a fun addition to my Alexa device.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2020

Review Text: We used a ‘stoplight nanny’ app for my older kids which was no longer available for my now 2 y/o. We came across the glow when searching for a sleep trainer alarm clock and is great! Brightness options are super helpful and easy to teach my daughter when it’s ok to get up each day. One problem I have is with the schedule. To activate the schedule and have the red light turn on at night we need to keep the light on all day, if we turn it off, the schedule is turned off. Minor issue, but now we keep the light on all day.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2021

Review Text: Tapping seems to be fairly responsive. My 8 month old loves swatting at it and watching the colors change. Good amount of light for a nightlight, don't expect this to be used as a reading lamp but is what I expected given the 100 lumens spec.I change this review from 2 stars to 4. When I first got the device I could not create a routine with the Echo Glow and was pretty frustrated. The next day I received a call from Amazon support and they had informed me that the device had to update and indeed did update later the prior day. Apparently I tried creating a routine before the device had a chance to update.Everything considering I am happy with the device. The reason for the 4 starts is that I think I found a bug when creating a routine. If I create a routine where it turns the device on, then ramps the brightness down to any level over any period of time, then turn the device off, the Ramp Brightness action will not execute, nor the turn device off. I found that if you remove the device off action, it works as intended, except it wont turn the device off. Maybe be you need a delay between the two actions? Would be nice if there was a debug mode and the minimum time for ramp up/down of 5 min makes testing painfully slow.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2019

Review Text: Not sure what to say about this, my toddler loves it and always wants it down on his task table.. so I really haven't tried to see what else it can do. Review Text: I've only had this for a few minutes, but so far it works as advertised. It's a nice little lamp, has a pleasant glow, and some fun features. I had a problem with set-up though and wanted to share the solution with you all: I tried the barcode and manual mode and neither worked. I just got a time-out error. Following the instructions to go to device support, I found after a little searching that you need to have your parental consent granted for your profile. We've had amazon devices for us and the kids for years, but apparently this had never come up before, because we were all set to "Not Granted". Once I updated our permissions (easy process) the Glow set up easily. It is unfortunate that this information is not communicated to you in the app as the reason why set-up can't occur and you have to go digging for it. But hopefully this will help others out there.  Once it was set up it worked great. I'll update my review if we come across any issues.

Review Text: The light was very hard to connect to the WiFI, and when it did, it didn't last very long.  Within the span of one day, I had to remove and reconnect the light to my network.  After the third time, I gave up.  Also, the fact that it doesn't have a speaker or mic was highly disappointing.Edit: I got a replacement and have the exact same problem.  It connects to the network and my Alexas work in turning on/off/changing colors.  However, next morning, again, it didn’t work.As a tap light, it’s cute and my kid likes it, she wants to keep it as a light.  As a smart light, it’s terrible.  Horrible quality issue with the “smart” side.Also, the fact that it’s called “Echo” is very misleading.  As you will see in other reviews, there is neither a mic or speaker on this device.  It’s pretty horrible that they couldn’t even put an Echo Dot into the base.Second Edit: Apparently I had to connect my Glow to a hotspot to get it to patch.  The patch helped for 4 days until it started acting up again.  I just had to reconnect again...Third Edit: I had to connect it to my Glow to get yet another patch (166) and now it seems like it's back to its old self where it connects once and refuses to be acknowledged as a connected device until I reset and resync again.  Given that I have to connect it to a hotspot to get it to patch, I'm willing to bet the wifi is just terrible on it.  I know it's not my internet because my phone gets great speeds and it's literally sitting next to an Echo Dot that works just fine.

Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2019

Review Text: Two ancillary points to be made about the device itself: the light is not bright enough to use for reading, and the device is very, very small. The pictures don't really tell you how small it is.But more importantly, your family's and specifically your child's privacy will be lost with the use of the device.This review is not about Alexa listening in on your child's conversations. It is about Amazon availing themselves of the fact that the device was created for children so they can tap into all the information your Amazon account might hold on the children. When you set it up, Alexa tells you that you MUST give parental consent to be able to use the lamp. Even if no child is using the lamp or if there is no child in the home.But here's the kicker: in giving parental consent to your children's profiles, you are also giving Alexa consent to your own! JUST TO TURN ON A LIGHT!The disclosure reads:"Your permission will apply to the following profiles:For certain Amazon kid services, like FreeTime on Alexa, we need permission to collect personal information. Your consent will apply to Amazon's collection of personal infomration in connection with all kid services requiring permission."It then goes on to list all the profiles under your Amazon account to which you are granting it access. Then you put in your Amazon password. Then you put in a 6 digit code they text you. Then you read a parental consent form (Am I checking in to a skydiving facility with my child here, or just turning on a lamp?!) that includes the following statement:"...children may share and we may collect personal information...(which) could include, for example, name, birthdate, contact information (including phone numbers and e-mail addresses), voice, photos, videos, location, certain activity and device information, and certain other types of information..."This is vile and offensive. Amazon is so desperate to get at your family's information that they use a child's lamp as an excuse to access it, all in the name of your child's protection.I could not rail against a device more than I do this one.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2020

Review Text: I purchased this for myself (no children in the home) and I am loving it. I had been using a nightlight skill on my Echo for a few years but sometimes Alexa had a hard time understanding my sleepy voice and by the time I said "Alexa make my night light glow" 3-4 times until she finally understood what I was saying I was wide awake lol. This little light is perfect. I still use Alexa to turn it on & I use it several times a night from the time I go to bed and then get up for the day & thus far, Alexa has understood me every time. I named it Archie & I just give Alexa the command to turn Archie on/off, increase/ decrease brightness, etc. I like the fact that I can adjust the brightness  - for example, when I first go to bed I like it a little brighter when I am arranging my pillows (I call it nesting); sometimes I leave it on all night. Having green eyes makes me very sensitive to lights especially at night & this gives me the option of changing to a color that does not make me squint or wake me up in the dead of night. I prefer the rotating colors but you can set it for a solid color or a campfire effect. It does have a disco effect but I haven't found much use for that but I am sure the kids would love that. You can set a timer or use it to help wake you up. I have 4 cats & it helps me see who is on the bed with me in the dark. I used to like it pitch black in the room but after a health scare this past summer I added a constant nightlight in my bedroom and I had yet to find one that didn't bother my eyes. I read this was coming out & pre-ordered it in September and I am glad that I waited & got this before buying anything else. I am all about Amazon and Alexa enabled devices & this is definitely a useful tool to add to my collection of devices in my home. You can change the setting from Alexa enabled to tapping the light to turn it off & on but mine is not on my nightstand and that wouldn't work for me. I don't see a need to have one in every room but I am sure if I had children in the home they would all want one. I remember when my daughter was a baby I installed a red bulb in a lamp in her room because I had read it would allow you to see without causing the wake up effects of a regular bulb. This would have been great to have back then & I could have experimented with different colors to see which worked best for my situation. The rotating colors blend seamlessly from one to the next creating a soothing effect if you are looking at it. I just got it so I can't speak as to how long it will last or what to do if the bulb(s) go out but I am sure a call to customer service will result in a quick answer when/if that time comes. There is no batteries so a power outage will be miserable since I am already attached to the convenience of it. I would definitely purchase this as a gift for a small child or expectant mother & I think that they would be delighted.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2019

Review Text: This was recently given to me as a gift. It is a good device, not great, with some shortcomings. Yes, it is made in China, says that right on the bottom of the device. Hopefully many of these are software issues that will improve with future updates.Out of the box, it is an attractive light with a quality feeling glass dome, so be careful that it doesn’t get dropped and broken, especially when being used by chilldren. The power cord is a shiny white cord and plug that looks like something from the Apple universe, and it also has a large tag that has to be cut off, or annoyingly left in place. I had to be careful not to nick the power cord when cutting it off. I guess if this cord needs a warning, then every corded device that a person can buy needs a warning. And in order to activate the device, I had to go online, sign an Amazon electronic consent form, and enter my credit card CVV code, or it would not let me use the device. Since Amazon already has my credit card information, this was not so much a financial privacy issue, as just annoying. They do this because the device is marketed to children, but to my knowledge, a lot of toys can be bought on line from Amazon without signing consent forms. Maybe it was just put there on advice of Amazon’s legal team. I wondered if they want a consent form for seizure prone children, maybe because the light can be made to flash different colors, as in Disco mode, or flicker, as in Campfire mode? If so, I did not see a seizure warning on the consent form.Set up is fairly easy, and the instructions are included in the box. I set it up from the app, not from a Amazon Echo device; the app was fast and easier. For my other WiFi enable lightbulbs, I just needed to say “Alexa, set up my WiFi devices,” and they all worked. That did not work with the Glow, but using the app was fast. The Glow does not have a microphone, so it doesn’t take voice commands.The first and most difficult problem is that frequently, and this is very frequently, the Glow loses the WiFi Connection. Commands are frequently and intermittently responded to by “Sorry, ‘Glow’ is not responding,” if you name the device Glow. I tried different names for the device, none of the names affected this intermittent non-responding problem. If I wait one minute, it might work again without doing anything different, then a minute later, it may or may not respond again. Even when it loses the WiFi connection, the tap function and the switch on the back still work. The WiFi connection can be reset by going through the setup function again with the Alexa app, but this is time consuming and frustrating, and then the device will work for a few minutes, then start losing the connection again. It could be that the WiFi connection is weak for this device, but at least where I have it set up, there is an Echo Plus and an Echo Tap nearby, and it is only about 40 feet from the router, and the other devices continue to work fine while the Glow loses the connection. The Echo Plus is just inches away and almost never loses the connection. In addition, I have found that unplugging the device, and plugging it back in and waiting half a minute generally will reset the connection as well. This is faster than going through the app. I would be curious to see if this is just the device I received, or if it is a problem with others as well.The light is not very bright. It functions fine for entertainment for kids, (it is marketed for this purpose, so this is not a negative) but the kids get tired of it after a few minutes. It works as a night light, haven’t had it long enough to see if it fails due to losing the WiFi connection, but the first night it worked fine. It can be set to augment an alarm to wake up in the morning, but for the most part it should be set to white light and maximum brightness, and even then, probably should have a traditional alarm right next to it, because it is not likely to be bright enough to rouse most people from sleep. When it is in a color mode, it is even less bright, as is to be expected for the most part.  It can work fairly well for mood lighting in an otherwise dim room.The timer works fine, but again since it frequently loses the WiFi connection, it may be frustrating to set the timer.Regarding software updates, like with all Amazon devices, some of these may improve with future new hardware generations of the product, and it is not always clear that older products will be supported with future software releases. Sometimes this is due to limitations of the old hardware. Sometimes there is the maddening suspicion that the limits on software updates for older hardware is a way to force consumers to give up on old hardware and purchase new hardware. This occurs with Apple, Amazon, and many other devices. However at least with Amazon, the devices are usually much more economically priced, and the value for the product sometimes make it worthwhile to upgrade the hardware.All in all, it is a nice device; it would be better if the WiFi connectivity issue was not there. It is a reasonable first iteration and inexpensively priced, though maybe priced higher than some similar devices that are not in the Echo/Alexa family. Not certain I would buy another, but if the WiFi connectivity is fixed, and if future lights are a little larger and brighter, I think its niche could be expanded and it will become more popular. For example, I could see a lot of people wanting an Alexa enable device such as this, and paying more for it, if it was larger, brighter, had an onboard Alexa enabled speaker, and could be used as a morning wake up timer to gradually fill the room with light, especially for those living in Northern climes where it is darker in the morning and darker for more of the day. Unfortunately, it is not there yet.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2019

Review Text: I bought this primarily to use as a wakeup light alarm. It’s works well enough and the price is nice.The good:- inexpensive, colorful smart bulb- easy to program via Alexa app- no mic, so no spying in the bedroomThe not so good:- bulb does not get very bright. More like a nightlight or dimmer nightstand light. Look elsewhere if you need a brighter light.- no mic, so if you want to use voice commands, you need a separate device (but I actually prefer the lack of mic for my purposes)- it would be nice if they had a built-in clock display like the Echo Dot since I imagine most people will use this on their nightstand.- it would be nice if they had a sunrise sequence for lighting; one that goes from red to orange to yellow to white.  And, although you can program the light to ramp up/down the brightness over a period of 5-60 minutes, it does not always do so very smoothly. I have mine set to ramp up over 10 minutes, but it does so in a stepwise fashion instead of gradually increasing the brightness at a consistent pace over that 10 minute period.

Review Text: I bought this for my autistic teenage daughter in order to: aid her daily routines; provide some low level colored light; and encourage her to speak to Alexa. I'm not sure that it would be much more than just a $30 gimmick without similarly specific wants.minus one star...Connecting it to my WiFi was very clunky and extremely tasking with some of the smallest font sizes that I have ever had to read. I opted to set it up via a Fire Tablet's Alexa App. IMPORTANT: if you lock down your WiFi to pre-defined Mac addresses, then you'll be happy to know that the Mac address is provided on the bottom of the box. In a font size of freakin' two.I immediately created four daily time routines for it, and I look forward to seeing them happen real time. (i.e. 7am Alexa says "Good morning", turn light on with bright solid gold color)Kudos that Alexa could immediately identify and control the device by name on my Fire TV Cube.One week later (plus one star)..this item has exceeded our expectations during morning routines. We look forward to using it more as Alexa learns new skills.

Review Text: I preordered this without really reading the full specs. I thought this had Alexa built in, it doesn’t. Not a huge deal as I have a bunch of Alexas already, but I was hoping it could function as an alarm clock and night light without another Alexa device in the room, it can’t. I bought this as an adjunct to my Echo Show. I use my show exclusively as an alarm clock. I know it can do a crap ton more, but honestly, I don’t need it to because I always have my iPad on hand. I love the show as an alarm clock especially because my wake up time differs from day to day and I hate fiddling with alarm clock settings. The voice commands are so nice and I like having the clock face to look at. The one thing I wish the show had is a light. I like a soft glow while winding down. Or, the ability to turn on a low light via voice commands for my midnight trips to the potty. (The show has a crappy flash light app that doesn’t allow you to change the brightness via voice commands.) I saw this echo glow and thought it was the solution to my echo show problems. And it totally is. Still think Amazon missed the boat by not including a night light with the show. And likewise, I think the glow should include a built in Alexa. But, they don’t, and having both is a doable workaround. The end result is that show plus glow gives me my perfect bedside setup. The only thing missing is a usb charging port. How I would love to plug my phone into my Alexa at night.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2019

Review Text:
Your browser does not support HTML5 video.


   This was so much better than expected!  My kiddo had a night light, stop light and an old iPad that played white noise and was her clock.  Between the new echo show and this light we replaced all of them.  At night she sets her light to the color she wants and then when it’s ok for her to get out of bed I have a routine set for the light to turn green.  She can change the color and brightness with voice or a tap.  For all her pretend play we set up routines for “Let’s go camping” which has a cool warm flickering kind of light and I set the Alexa to do nighttime forest sounds.  We also set up a routine for “Let’s have a dance party!” The light goes to disco mode where it flashes between all the lights (shown in the video) and music starts to play.  She can’t wait to set up more routines for all her playtime!  I am now contemplating one for my room.

Review Text: I'm not one to write reviews but this was disappointing. Review Text: I was honestly surprised by all the negative reviews on this product. This light is everything the description says it is. It is not advertised as an echo dot. It is a light. So you cannot talk directly to it. You can, however, ask Alexa to turn it on. You can name the device to distinguish it from other smart devices connected in your Alexa app.I saw another review claiming you cannot turn the light off in touch mode; this is not true. There is a power button on the back of the device.You can schedule the light to turn on to specific programmed patterns on certain days and times. For example, if you wanted the firelight setting every weekday evening, this could be set to auto turn on.The light is also fully controllable from the app on your phone. You can open it anytime and see if the light is on/off. You can also dim or brighten the light.My only complaint was that it was a bit of a battle to get it connected to our network. We had to power cycle the light multiple times before it finally successfully went into pair mode. The light will flash when in pair mode. Once in pair mode, it take approximately 1 min to connect. It is only compatible with 2.4ghz networks. If you have 5ghz only, it will not connect.I 100% recommend this light.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2021

Review Text: When I purchased this lamp, I kept my expectations reasonable as Amazon was very clear, this is a lamp.  Not a speaker, not anything else.  And I can honestly say, I love it so much I have three and number four is on its way.I deal with migraines on a chronic level. I currently use three of these in my bedroom and I have manipulated them to the exact percentage of light that I need.  That way it does not hurt my head further. If it is all too much, all I have to say is “goodnight Alexa” and all three turn off simultaneously.It has also enhances the work my husband does with 3-D printers. The picture attached is a lithophane he made for me.  There are two Echo Glows behind it.You can make it change color simply by tapping it.  (Or you can even turn that feature off, which I have.)Plenty of options on the color of light it displays.Set up was amazingly simple.Such a great device.  I am even debating whether to buy one as a gift for my mother.You will love this!
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2020

Review Text: Updated 02MAR20:So unfortunately I can no longer recommend the Glow.  I bought this at end of September when it was released, however did not unbox it until after Christmas as it was a gift for my 10 year old (who needs a nightlight). Everything was fine until it stopped communicating one night - to never connect again. (This happened once or twice previously and I just unplugged it and plugged it back in, reconnected and moved on). Now, no matter how many times I tried to connect, delete, reinstall, etc - it just would not connect to wireless. It is right next to an Echo Dot that is not having any issues, however I moved it right next to my router and tried different networks and even a hotspot and it just would not connect to wireless. Tried different devices to connect it with (iPhone, iPad, PC). Just spent over an hour with Amazon (doing the same things I've already tried many times......) and was told that it's out of warranty. I was put on hold while the customer service rep checked with a supervisor to see if I could get a one time extension on the warranty so that I could get a replacement (his suggestion, not mine) and then after a long wait was told that no, it was not approved. I wonder when this does get approved? Apparently not in my case. However, they will give me 15% off of a new one! Seriously? I have a device that worked for less than two full months and I'm going to by another? Thanks Amazon.Now I can see in other reviews that this has also been an issue which makes me even more mad that they are not replacing it. (First they blamed it on my wireless, then my device (iPhone) that I was using to set it up, and then ultimately after going through all of the motions again they know that it is the device but sorry... out of warranty). I think that it doesn't cost them much to replace these for the customers having this issue. Would've went a long way with me but I am definitely not planning on purchasing any additional Amazon devices in the future.Initial review: I got this primarily as a night light in my 10 year olds room. It’s about the size of a softball and I use either my Alexa app or Echo to control it. You can also activate a tap feature via the app that allows you to change color, etc by tapping the Glow directly. I like that there are many different color and pattern options (and even more combinations recently added automatically). My son likes to set his Glow to ‘ocean’ and then have Echo play ocean sounds softly at night. Perfect combination. I also set it up so that the Glow lights up in the morning on school days as a wake up alarm. (I also added Echo to also say a good morning at same time). I love that we can control the brightness of the Glow as well. You can make the light as soft as a small night light or bright enough to light up the entire room. The Glow stays cool to the touch as well.Overall I love it and recommend, whether or not you have Echo or another device in room.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2019

Review Text: Update: Still one star, but a better description why. TL;DR at the end.Amazon called me after I posted a one star review - they wanted to talk through the issues I was having and understand what was going on. I don't think we got anywhere on the call, though now I think I have a better explanation of what went wrong.My realization hinged upon a weird point in my conversation with the Amazon tech - he seemed to think the Echo Glow was plugged into an Echo Flex, but I explained that, no, it's a standalone unit that comes with its own power supply. This bothered me and so... I tried plugging it into my Echo Flex.And, connected to the Echo Flex, it works very well. The Glow has its own WiFi internally, but there's no need for that when connected to an Echo Flex. And the Echo Flex seems to remember its own configuration, while the Glow is designed not to.I don't think all parents want Alexa in our child's bedroom, we wanted a standalone device to help with bedtime and gloomy mornings in winter. The Glow ships with its own power supply, but it's crippled if you use it in that configuration. It can't store settings, so you have to reset it every time your child unplugs it or your house loses power, and sometimes it just forgets. As others have mentioned, the "Simple Setup" that works so well with the Echo Flex just... doesn't. You have to go through a manual setup process if Simple Setup fails - it usually does on my device - and if the Glow is not in the same room as my WiFi Access Point, Manual Setup also fails and has to be rerun several times before it succeeds. As it happens, my WiFi Access Point is not in my child's bedroom, so the process is somewhat frustrating.But if you plug it into an Echo Flex, it's immediately recognized and available for Alexa voice commands and control via the app.The standalone operation of the Glow when not connected to a Flex, then, seems really to be an afterthought, and for many parents, likely less useful compared to a $2 nightlight or a Hue bulb. Maybe the Flex+Glow is the normal use case, but for me, it's not.TL;DR: If you only plan on using the Echo Glow as an accessory plugged in to an Echo Flex, it's fine. Otherwise, it's junk.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2020

Review Text: I preordered this for my 10 year old son, who also has an Echo Dot in his bedroom. The Echo Glow arrived yesterday and he loves it!Previously, he had a night light that requires him to manually adjust the time (it only worked on a timer, up to 995 minutes, and pressing a button on the back would increase the timer by 5 minutes) and the colors as well. It would take him a long time to get the nightlight setup and my husband and I suspect that he was using it as a bedtime delay tactic.We are all very pleased with the Echo Glow! My son enjoyed the various modes and colors to pick from - and my husband and I love that it can quickly and easily be turned on with the Echo Dot or with the Alexa app from our phones.The ability to adjust brightness is amazing! When set to white and 100% brightness, the light is very bright! My son even commented that it would be too bright to sleep with it on that setting.Overall, we are all very happy with the Echo Glow and we already plan on buying more!
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2019

Review Text: The best little light for any room. We chose to put ours in the hallway. There has been a problem with this home for years. It's old and has a long dark hallway that you literally need a flashlight to see to get to the bathroom at night or even in the daytime on cloudy days. There is no wiring in the hallway either to install a light. It was my Mother's home before she passed  and it has always been this way, until now! This WONDERFUL little lamp was EASILY plugged into the bathroom outlet next to the door. I ran the USB nice long cable out and with it was able to use a double sided adhesive and mount the Echo light directly on the wall ! You can controll it with your Echo dot or other device to power it off and on as needed. No more flashlights !!! We literally played with the light for an hour cycling it through all the light and color adaptations it has. The light is also easily controlled by selecting your request in the Alexa app on your phone or by voice on your app. The brightness can be adjusted from 1% of its visible brightness to 100% . It is quite bright at 100% and I was amazed how much light it put out having a "frosted" effect shading. My son enjoys the color selections and gave us a good idea by suggesting that if we are going to the bathroom that we choose a color for Alexa to change the light indicating that someone is occupying the restroom. That prevents a trip down the hall only to find out someone is in there. There are also bedrooms down at the very end of the hall so it helps to get to them as well. I'll post some pictures tonight and I took some today to show the brightness levels. I also connected the USB cord to a portable power charging unit and it worked just as easily there, so it could even be used that way for camping or power outages. All said and done this is the most versatile light I have ever owned and I literally could think of at least 20 more places to use this. Hope this helps you decide.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2020

Review Text: I purchased this for the sole purpose of using it as anight light... because I'll admit... Red, Blue, Yellow, Green, Purple, etc.And I can tell Alexa to turn my light On or turn my light Offso I don't have to get up and turn it off myself. And I learnedI can set a timer for it to turn off after a certain amount oftime. That will be convenient too. Review Text: This light is brighter than I thought. I bought this light mainly because I've been visually impaired for over a year now, and I found out red light doesn't trigger my photophobia. It works great for that. I'm not a child, I didn't buy this for a child, but you have to fill out the parental consent form anyways on Amazon. Anyways, there is no lag when I tell my Echo Dot to turn this thing on, although sometimes it seems the Echo Dot have some trouble understanding what colour I want this light to be be set to when I combine it with the turn on command (I'm sure Amazon can easily fix this). Sometimes Alexa does tell me Echo Dot is not responding, but it will still follow through with the command, not sure why.My main complaint and why I took off 2 stars is, other than by voice, you can only turn this light on and off with the small button on the back of the light. There is a tap feature on this device which I've turned off as I almost never use any other colour other than red. I wish there would be an option in the Alexa app to turn on tap on and tap off mode so you don't have to reach behind the light and press the little switch. I don't think this would be very hard to program in.Overall nice light, but Amazon could add in some new features to make this light easier to use.

Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2020

Review Text: After reading the reviews, I still decided to get the glow. Now that I have it, I have realized there are some misconceptions about what this device is and is not. It is NOT a kids echo, they make one of those...get that if you need a smart speaker for kids. So what is this then? Think of it as blinkers or flashers for your car.You can add the glow to your existing echo routines. Maybe you have a go to bed routine, you can add this as a nightlight that gradually turns off. I have this set as a wake light in the master bedroom, it goes from off to 100% light over the course of 30 minutes for a relaxing wake alarm. I also added a step in my good morning routine to turn it off. By the way, I read some reviews that stated there is no way to turn it off without using your voice on an echo...that is not the case, there is a button on the back that turns it off. For those with babies, you can add a routine for checking on the baby that turns the glow on at a reduced level to not wake the baby.You can also use this as a visual alarm for the hearing impaired or as a visual cue for you or your kids to do something. If you take care of someone and need to make sure they can reach you in another room if they fall or need help, you can put glows in every room, add them to a group and create a routine that makes the glows light up like a siren if someone says “Alexa, get help”. The Built-in rainbow timer functions are pretty cool, especially for kids.All-in-all, it’s a good every day nightlight and wake alarm. It comes in handy for alerts and timers. It is not an echo, so don’t expect one. If you don’t have an echo, you can still use it as a nightlight or wake alarm on a schedule using the Alexa app to setup the times.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2020

Review Text: For everyone complaining READ THE TITLE. This was made for KIDS. While yes it could be a good hue alternative,  it’s currently advertised as for kids for timers, activities, etc. I’m sure amazon will improve and add more features for people to use it for different reasons such as silent alarms, event lights, etc.I just set it up pretty quick for my 6 year old daughter. She loves it and my almost 2 year old loves touching it to change colors!My only con is getting the right commands, sometimes Alexa doesn’t understand for some reason, I’m sure they’re fixing the kinks.Amazon echo user since OG echo day 1.5 stars for now for what it does and cost. Exactly as advertised.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2019

Review Text: Although the "ok to wake" clock worked reasonably well for my oldest, my 3yo quickly figured out how to open the back and change the time and programming, rendering it useless as a sleep management tool. So needless to say I was excited at the prospect of the Echo Glow. A simple, programmable light that would be tougher for kids to tamper with. Set up was pretty easy and the first night went fairly well - my son was very excited to pick out his sleep and wake colors and proudly bounded into our room the next morning saying "I waited until my clock turned blue." However, this morning, he bounded in at 5:15am with the same proclamation, even though the clock was not due to turn blue until more than an hour later. I sleepily trudged into his room and discovered that yes, his clock was in fact blue. After looking at the Alexa app programming, I still have no idea why. My son was despondent at being told to go back to bed, and trust in the Glow has been shattered.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2019

Review Text: So I purchased this device like many others as a pre-order. I was super excited for my five year old to open it. I was disappointed at the size, its the same size as an Echo Dot (1st/2nd gen) a little smaller than 3rd gen echo dot.  *but my fault for not reading the dimensions and it sitting next to an Echo Dot* It's definitely a night light and not a "lamp" as they claim. I feel like they should not have classified this as an Echo Device as it is NOT an ECHO and REQUIRES and ECHO. For us that was fine as she has her kids echo dot. But honestly all it is, is a smart light. I wish it were a little brighter being we have the option to dim it and dim by percentage a little more lumen would have done this great, but again this is my misunderstanding of "LAMP" versus "Night Light". Multiple colors and some colors have interchangeable names like she can say "teal" and it will turn the light "cyan". The "tap" is SUPER sensitive. It's sitting on my desk so I can "play" while she's at school and it picks up every time I hit the keyboard. Then other times it's not sensitive enough little one practically has to slap it and to avoid abuse of the light ESPECIALLY BEING THERE IS NO WARRANTY FOR A KIDS PRODUCT she sticks to voice commands. The modes are pretty great she really enjoys "Disco" but Alexa has a hard time putting the light in different modes. I have been able to get her to put it in campfire mode by voice though "Alexa, put light in campfire mode" but then when i say "Alexa, put light in rainbow mode" she responds with "okay" but doesn't make that change. So we are still troubleshooting this part. The button on the back is NOT a power button and will disconnect the device.  So to break it down:::PROs:Cute Smart LightVivid and Expansive Color SchemeEasy for kids to controlCan be used with Alexa routinesCONs:NO WARRANTY ON A KIDS DEVICESensitivity to tap is all over the placeDoes not sync with musicIs NOT an Echo device it's JUST a lightShould be advertised as a nightlight not a "lamp" (Tiny and just bright *enough*)Will update if I notice more as I play with it. Only got it yesterday :)
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2019
